Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mechanical Material Removal Processes for Biological Tissue in Cardiovascular Procedures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to develop experimentally validated physics-based models of the mechanical material removal processes in biological tissue machining. The approach is to characterize unique aspects of biological tissue machining in four related research activities. 1) Describe the transition from material deformation and plowing to material removal. The specific objective is to develop machining test systems and material removal models for the new classes of work materials being studied. 2) Develop and validate machining force and debris size models. The specific objective is to predict machined surface and subsurface damage that is directly related to medical treatment success. 3) Create artery deformation models that are directly linked to material removal models. The specific goal is to infer short- and long-term effects in the project application process of atherectomy, the removal of plaque from blood vessels. 4) Characterize the dynamic behaviour and effects of long, flexible tool drive systems on tool-work interactions. The specific objective is to provide realistic medical procedure inputs to machining process and work damage models.

If successful, fundamental machining studies and research results will be widely useful in many tissue machining processes. The benefits of this research will be improved performance of commonly used medical devices, new machining test systems, and new tissue machining models that include work material deformation models directly related to possible machining damage and surgical treatment success. The project will extend the integrated activity of manufacturing engineering, biomedical engineering and health care by immediately bringing together practicing professionals in engineering, medicine and medical device design who have committed to actively participate in the research. These individuals will bring with them graduate and undergraduate students and working technicians from these fields.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many medical procedures involve soft tissue deformation. For example, in angioplasty a balloon is inserted into an occluded artery and expanded to increase the size of the artery lumen and so increase the size of the blood flow channel. This procedure may be followed by inserting a stent into the artery to maintain the expansion of the treated region. In atherectomy a small grinding or cutting tool is introduced into the artery, moved to the site of a plaque buildup and rotated to remove the plaque and so increase the artery lumen size. In these and other procedures the deformation imposed on the tissue produces beneficial results, but unwanted deformation must be avoided. Obtaining optimum immediate and long term treatment outcomes requires detailed knowledge of the effects of the imposed deformation on the changes in tissue characteristics. The goal of the research was to quantitatively characterize the effects of imposed deformation on the mechanical state of the artery during and after such soft tissue procedures.

            In this research numerical simulations of atherectomy and angioplasty were created backed by physical experiments to assure accurate descriptions of the procedures and for simulation validation. Artery and plaque material behavior models were developed to truly describe the effects of the wide range of deformation imposed in atherectomy and angioplasty. The stress state and mechanical energy input to the artery-plaque structure were calculated. The mechanical energy input was quantitatively described since this is the physical process causing changes in the artery material. Simulation results showed the deformation and energy input in plaque and plaque-free areas of the artery. The critical high energy regions were at boundaries between plaque and the artery wall. In addition to describing the state of the artery during treatment, the research produced descriptions of the change of artery stiffness due to plaque disruption. This result is significant since efficient blood circulation depends critically on the elasticity of the artery.

            The overall result of this research is the detailed description of the mechanical consequences of imposing deformation on soft tissue in angioplasty and atherectomy procedures. The analysis techniques and results produced can be extended to other soft tissue treatments. The results will enable inclusion of basic understanding of the mechanical aspects of soft tissue deformation into the design, operation and development of medical treatments.

            This project had far reaching professional development impacts in addition to the specific research activities. Much of the research was conducted in association with a medical device industry partner. As part of this cooperation three graduate students spent separate summers full time with the industry partner obtaining a rich university-commercial sector experience. A distinctive result of this activity was a student being included on a patent application. Also, as a direct result of on-going research a graduate student was awarded a National Science Foundation Summer Internship for research at the National University of Singapore to study micro-level structural changes in arteries due to various kinds of mechanical loading.


Last Modified: 12/08/2016
Modified by: Barney E Klamecki
